title: Beyond Left and Right
sub_head: On the one hand, mixed dominance makes me who I am. On the other hand, I don’t know how or why.
body:
Recently I found myself with time on my hands, and I began to think about them. I’ve always written with my left hand, but about 50 years ago, when I was teaching English at Beaver College, I realized that I picked up a piece of chalk with my right hand when I was about to write on the blackboard. In recent years I’ve written shopping lists with my right hand because I write more clearly—albeit more slowly—with that hand. But I use my left hand for other kinds of writing, like editing something I’ve printed from the computer
When I tell people that I can write with either hand, they usually say: “So you’re ambidextrous.”
I’m not, though. I can’t throw a ball with my left hand, bat left-handed or play tennis left-handed. When I used to play basketball, I could never drive for a layup to my left. And jump shots were always with my right hand.
My right hand and arm are much stronger than my left. I open jars with my right hand, hold a hammer with my right hand, punch with my right hand, and pick up suitcases with my right hand. I hold the phone with my left hand, but that is supposedly a sign of right-handedness.
I use my left hand for most tasks that require fine motor skills. I brush my teeth with my left hand; I use a fork and spoon with my left hand. But I do some things requiring precision with my right hand. I use scissors and a screwdriver with my right hand. And I brush my hair with my right hand. I tried to use a screwdriver and scissors with my left hand. Couldn’t do it.
